entry.title: Flow matching for generative modeling
entry.content:
Design Philosophy

  • Given vector field / SDE / ODE: DDPM, Score-based SDE

  • Given flow: Elucidating the design space

  • Given density path: flow matching, action matching, interplorating between any two distributions

  • Given density path, there’s infinity flow / process satisfy this density path

  • The link between density path and dynamic: continuty equation

  • The path with the lowest shipping cost: optimal transport

  • Is the optimal transport path the best?

Introduction

  • Question behind: Given probility path, can we find a related dynamic?

  • Flow Matching (FM), a simulation-free approach for training CNFs based on** regressing vector ﬁelds** of ﬁxed conditional probability paths.

  • we ﬁnd that employing FM with diffusion paths results in a more robust and stable alternative for training diffusion models.

  • Flow Matching opens the door to training CNFs with other, non-diffusion probability paths.

    • An instance is using Optimal Transport (OT) displacement interpolation.

  • propose the Flow Matching objective

  • ﬁnd that conditional OT paths are simpler than diffusion paths, forming straight line trajectories whereas diffusion paths result in curved paths.

Preliminaries

Continuity Equation (transport equation)

Describe how the density evolves

  • State space to density space (Continuous dynamic to continuous equation)

  • Can we know** if a vector field \(v_t\) is generates a probability path **\(p_t\)? The anwser is the continuity equation.

  • It is a Partial Differential Equation (PDE) providing a necessary and sufﬁcient condition to ensuring that a vector ﬁeld \(v_t\) generates \(p_t\),

  • \[\frac{d}{d t} p_t(x)+\operatorname{div}\left(p_t(x) v_t(x)\right)=0\]
  • where the divergence operator, div, is defined respect to the special variable \(x = (x^1, \cdots, x^d)\), ie., \(\text{div} = \sum_{i=1}^d\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}\)

Two important objects

  • The probability path: \(p:[0,1] \times \mathbb{R}^d \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{>0}\)

  • Time-dependent vector ﬁeld: \(\phi:[0,1] \times \mathbb{R}^d \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^d\)

    • the vector field is defined via the ODE

    • \[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{d t} \phi_t(x) & =v_t\left(\phi_t(x)\right) \\ \phi_0(x) & =x\end{aligned}\]

Flow matching

Initial Flow Matching Objective

  • Data distribution: let \(x_1\) denote a random variable distributed according to some unknown data distribution \(q(x_1)\)

    • e.g. \(x_1\) is the cat, then \(q(x_1)\) is the distribution of cats

  • Prior: \(p_0 = p\) is a simple distribution, e.g., the standard normal distribution \(p(x) = \mathcal{N} (x \vert 0, I)\)

  • Probability path: \(p_t(x), t \in [0, 1]\), we hope \(p_1 \approx p_0\)

  • Flow Matching Objective: Given a target distribution \(p_t(x)\) and a corresponding vector field \(u_t(x)\), which generates \(p_t(x)\), we define the Flow matching objective as

    • \[\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{FM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{t \sim \mathcal{U}[0,1], x \sim p_t(x)}\left\|v_t(x, \theta)-u_t(x)\right\|^2\]

  • This objective is intractable: since we have no prior knowledge for \(p_t\)and \(u_t\)

    • we have many choices of \(p_t(x)\) that satisfy \(p_1(x) \approx q(x)\)

    • we generally don’t have access to a closed form \(u_t\) that generate desired \(p_t\)

Constructing \(p_t, u_t\) from conditional probability paths and vector fields

How to select a target probability path?

  • \(p_0(x \vert x_1)\): Given a particular data sample \(x_1\), e.g. an image of cat, we denote by \(p_t(x \vert x_1)\) a conditional probability path such that it satisfies \(p_0(x \vert x_1) = p(x)\) at time \(t=0\)

  • \(p_1(x \vert x_1)\): we design \(p_1(x \vert x_1)\) at \(t = 1\)to be a distribution concentrated around \(x = x_1\), e.g. \(p_1(x \vert x_1) = \mathcal{N}(x \vert x_1, \sigma^2 I)\), with a small standard deviation \(\sigma > 0\)

  • the marginal probability path: \(p_t(x)=\int p_t\left(x \mid x_1\right) q\left(x_1\right) d x_1\)

    • \[p_1(x)=\int p_1\left(x \mid x_1\right) q\left(x_1\right) d x_1 \approx q(x)\]

  • the marginal vector ﬁeld that generates \(p_t( \cdot \vert x_1)\): \(u_t(x)=\int u_t\left(x \mid x_1\right) \frac{p_t\left(x \mid x_1\right) q\left(x_1\right)}{p_t(x)} d x_1\)

:::info

  • Key observation: the marginal vector ﬁeld generates the marginal probability path :::

    Conditional flow matching (CFM)

  • we propose a simpler objective, which surprisingly will result in the same optima as the original objective.

    • \[\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CFM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{t \sim \mathcal{U}[0, 1], x_1 \sim q\left(x_1\right), x \sim p_t\left(x \mid x_1\right)}\left\|v_t(x)-u_t\left(x \mid x_1\right)\right\|^2\]
  • Why conditional : we can efﬁciently sample from \(p_t(x \vert x_1)\) and compute \(u_t(x \vert x_1)\)

:::info

  • **second key observation: The FM and CFM objectives have identical gradients w.r.t. **\(\theta\)

:::

Conditional Probability paths and vector fields

The construction of \(p_t(x \vert x_1)\) and \(u_t(x \vert x_1)\)

Design the conditional probability path

  • consider conditional probability paths of the form: \(p_t\left(x \mid x_1\right)=\mathcal{N}\left(x \mid \mu_t\left(x_1\right), \sigma_t\left(x_1\right)^2 I\right)\)

  • **Set the initial conditional distribution: **we set \(\mu_0 (x_1) = 0\) and \(\sigma_0(x_1) = 1\), so at \(t = 0\), all the conditional probability converge to the same Gaussian noise distribution, \(p(x) = \mathcal{N}(x \vert 0, I)\)

  • **Set the final conditional distribution: **we set \(\mu_1(x) = x_1\), \(\sigma_1(x_1) = \sigma_{\min}\), which is set sufficiently small so that \(p_1(x \vert x_1)\) is a concentrated Gaussian distribution centered at \(x_1\).

Design the flow

  • There is an inﬁnite number of vector ﬁelds that generate any particular probability path.

    • Given a \(p_t(x)\), there’s infinity number of \(u_t(x)\) satisfy continuty equation

    • e.g., adding a divergence free component to the continuity equation

    • when the distribution is rotation-invariant—rotational components leading to unnecessary extra compute

  • We select a canonical transformation for Gaussian distributions

    • \[\psi_t(x)=\sigma_t\left(x_1\right) x+\mu_t\left(x_1\right)\]
    • It is easy to prove that this flow satisfy the probability path above: \(p_t\left(x \mid x_1\right)=\mathcal{N}\left(x \mid \mu_t\left(x_1\right), \sigma_t\left(x_1\right)^2 I\right)\)

Calculate the vector field based on flow

  • This ﬂow then provides a vector ﬁeld that generates the conditional probability path: \(u_t\left(\psi_t(x) \mid x_1\right) = \frac{d}{d t} \psi_t(x)\)

  • Reparameterizing \(p_t(x \vert x_1)\) in terms of just \(x_0\) (since we define the flow, given \(x_0\), we can sample \(x_t\)), the CFM loss: \(\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CFM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{t, q\left(x_1\right), p\left(x_0\right)}\left\|v_t\left(\psi_t\left(x_0\right)\right)-\frac{d}{d t} \psi_t\left(x_0\right)\right\|^2\)

  • the unique vector ﬁeld that deﬁnes \(\psi_t\): \(u_t\left(x \mid x_1\right)=\frac{\sigma_t^{\prime}\left(x_1\right)}{\sigma_t\left(x_1\right)}\left(x-\mu_t\left(x_1\right)\right)+\mu_t^{\prime}\left(x_1\right)\). Consequently, \(u_t(x \vert x_1)\) generates the Gaussian path \(p_t(x \vert x_1)\)

entry.title: A Computational Framework For Solving Wassertein Lagrangian Flows

link.title: A Computational Framework For Solving Wassertein Lagrangian Flows

entry.content:
Preliminaries

Machanics

Curves: \(\gamma(t): [0:1] ightarrow \mathcal{X}\); Velocity \(\dot{\gamma_t} \in \mathcal{T}_{\gamma(t)} \mathcal{X}\); Lagrangian function: \(L(\gamma_t \dot{\gamma_t}, t)\).

Given two endpoints \(x_0, x_1 \in \mathcal{X}\), define the action as the time integral \(\mathcal{A}(\gamma)=\int_0^1 L\left(\gamma_t, \dot{\gamma}_t, t ight) d t\).

Minimize the action along all curves: \(c\left(x_0, x_1 ight)=\inf _{\gamma \in \Pi\left(x_0, x_1 ight)} \mathcal{A}(\gamma)=\inf _{\gamma_t} \int_0^1 L\left(\gamma_t, \dot{\gamma}_t, t ight) d t \quad\).

Lagrangian flows: we refer to the optimizing curves \(\gamma^*(x_0, x_0)\) as Lagrange flows, which satisfy the Euler-Lagrange equation \( rac{d}{d t} rac{\partial}{\partial \dot{\gamma}_t} L\left(\gamma_t, \dot{\gamma}_t, t ight)= rac{d}{d \gamma_t} L\left(\gamma_t, \dot{\gamma}_t, t ight)\).

Assume that \(L(\gamma_t, \dot{\gamma}_t, t)\) is strictly convex in the velocity \(\dot{\gamma}_t\), then we can obtain an equivalent, Hamiltonian perspective. Define the Hamiltonian \(H\left(\gamma_t, p_t, t ight)\) as the Legendre transform of \(L\) with respect to \(\dot{\gamma}_t\),

\[H\left(\gamma_t, p_t, t ight)=\sup _{\dot{\gamma}_t}\left\langle\dot{\gamma}_t, p_t ight angle-L\left(\gamma_t, \dot{\gamma}_t, t ight)\]

The Euler-Lagrange equations can be written as Hamiltion’s equation in phase space \(\dot{\gamma}_t= rac{\partial}{\partial p_t} H\left(\gamma_t, p_t, t ight) \quad \dot{p}_t=- rac{\partial}{\partial \gamma_t} H\left(\gamma_t, p_t, t ight)\)

Basic of math

**Deﬁnition (Image measure or push forward measure): **take a map \(T:X ightarrow Y\) and a probability measure \(\mu \in \mathcal{P} (Y)\) as: \(\left(T_{\#} \mu ight)(A):=\mu\left(T^{-1}(A) ight)\) for any \(A \in \mathcal{B}(Y)\)

Deﬁnition (Tangent space): Given a point \(p \in M\), the tangent space \(T_p M \subset \mathbb{R}^D\) of \(M\) at \(p\) is defined as \(T_p M:=\{\dot{\gamma}(0) \mid \gamma:(-1,1) ightarrow M, \gamma(0)=p\}\). Intuitively, the tangent space contains all the directions tangent to \(M\) at \(p\).

Deﬁnition (Riemannian distance): Given two points \(x, y \in M\), their Riemannian distance \(d_{M}(x, y)\) is defined as \(d_M(x, y):=\inf \left\{\int_a^b \vert \dot{\gamma}(t) \vert d t \mid \gamma:[a, b] ightarrow M, \gamma(a)=x, \gamma(b)=y ight\}\).

\(X\) and \(Y\) are locally compact, separable, and complete metric spaces.

Deﬁnition (Minimizing geodesic): A curve \(\gamma : [a,b] ightarrow M\) with constant speed such that \(\gamma(a) = x, \gamma(b) = y\), and whose length is equal to \(d_M (x, y)\), is called a minimizing geodesic.

Transport maps & coupling

**Definition (Transport map): **Given \(\mu \in \mathcal{P}(X)\) and \(v \in \mathcal{P}(Y)\), a map \(T: X ightarrow Y\) is called a transport map from \(\mu\) to \(v\) if \(T_{\#} \mu = v\)

Definition (Coupling or transport plan): We call \(\gamma \in \mathcal{P}(X imes Y)\) a coupling of \(\mu\) and \(v\) if

\(\left(\pi_X ight)_{\#} \gamma=\mu \quad ext { and } \quad\left(\pi_Y ight)_{\#} \gamma=v ext {, }\) where \(\pi_X(x, y)=x, \quad \pi_Y(x, y)=y \quad orall(x, y) \in X imes Y\). We denote by \(\Gamma(\mu, v)\) the set of couplings of \(\mu\) and \(v\).

**Remark: **Given \(\mu\) and \(v\), the set \(\Gamma(\mu, v)\) is always nonempty, indeed the product measure \(\gamma = \mu \otimes v\) (defined by \(\int \phi(x, y) d \gamma(x, y)=\int \phi(x, y) d \mu(x) d u(y)\)) for every \(\phi: X imes Y ightarrow \mathbb{R}\) is a coupling.

Remark (Transport map vs. coupling). Let \(T: X ightarrow Y\) satisfy \(T_{\#} \mu=v\). Consider the map\(\operatorname{Id} imes T: X ightarrow X imes Y\), i.e., \(x \mapsto(x, T(x))\), and define\(\gamma_T:=(\operatorname{Id} imes T)_{\#} \mu \in \mathcal{P}(X imes Y)\), we claim that \(\gamma_T \in \Gamma(\mu, v)\). This proves that any transport map \(T\) includes a coupling \(\gamma_T\).

Optimal Transport

Two kinds of formulation: Monge formulation and Kantorovich formulation

Sketch

How to calculate the action of \( ho_t\)

Given Lagrangian function \(\mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]\), the action is \(A_L[ ho_t]=\int_0^1 \mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight] d t\)

Recall the definition of the Legendre transform for \(\mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]\) strictly convex in \(\dot{ ho}_t\),

\[ egin{aligned} & \mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]=\sup _{\dot{ ho}_t \in \mathcal{T}_{ ho_t} \mathcal{P}} \int \dot{ ho}_t s_t d x_t-\mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight] \ & \mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]=\sup _{s_t \in \mathcal{T}_{ ho_t}^* \mathcal{P}} \int \dot{ ho}_t s_t d x_t-\mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]\end{aligned}\]

The action \(A_L[ ho_t]\) is the solution to the inneroptimization

\[\mathcal{A}_{\mathcal{L}}\left[ ho_t ight]=\sup _{s_t} \int s_1 \mu_1 d x_1-\int s_0 \mu_0 d x_0-\int_0^1\left(\int rac{\partial s_t}{\partial t} ho_t d x_t+\mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight] ight) d t\]

How to minimize the action

The optimization\(\mathcal{S}=\inf _{ ho_t \in \Gamma\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\} ight)} \mathcal{A}_{\mathcal{L}}\left[ ho_t ight]=\inf _{ ho_t \in \Gamma\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\} ight)} \int_0^1 \mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight] d t\) is equivalent to the following dual

\[\mathcal{S}=\inf _{ ho_t \in \Gamma\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\} ight)} \sup _{s_t} \int s_1 \mu_1 d x_1-\int s_0 \mu_0 d x_0-\int_0^1\left(\int rac{\partial s_t}{\partial t} ho_t d x_t+\mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight] ight) d t\]

So we have two goals

  • Inner optimization: evaluating the action functional \(\mathcal{A}_{\mathcal{L}}\left[ ho_t ight]\) for a given curve \( ho_t\)

  • **Outer optimization: **optimizing the action over curves \( ho_t \in \Gamma\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\} ight)\) satisfying the desired constraints

Hamiltonian optimality conditions

\( rac{\partial ho_t}{\partial t}= rac{\delta}{\delta s_t} \mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]\) and \( rac{\partial s_t}{\partial t}=- rac{\delta}{\delta ho_t} \mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]\)

A special class of Lagrangians

Definition 3.1 ((Dual) Linearizability). A Lagrangian \(\mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]\) is dual linearizable if the corresponding Hamiltonian \(\mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]\) can be written as a linear functional of the density \( ho_t\). In other words, \(\mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]\) is linearizable if there exist functions \(K^*\left(x_t, s_t, t ight)\), and \(U\left(x_t, s_t, t ight)\) such that \(\mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]=\int\left(K^*\left(x_t, s_t, t ight)+U\left(x_t, s_t, t ight) ight) ho_t d x_t\)

Parameterization

We parameterize \(s_t\) as a neural network \(s_t(x, heta)\), we parameterize the distribution path \( ho_t(x, \eta)\) as a generative model \(x_t=(1-t) x_0+t x_1+t(1-t) \mathrm{NNET}\left(t, x_0, x_1, \eta ight), \quad x_0 \sim \mu_0, \quad x_1 \sim \mu_1\).

Reparameterization trick

For linearizable dual objectives, we optimize

\[ egin{aligned} \operatorname{LOSS}( heta, \eta)=\min _\eta \max _ heta \int s_1(x, heta) \mu_1 d x_1-\int s_0(x, heta) \mu_0 d x_0 \ \quad-\int_0^1 \int\left( rac{\partial s_t}{\partial t}(x, heta)+K^*\left(s_t(x, heta), t ight)+U\left(s_t(x, heta), t ight) ight) ho_t(x, \eta) d x d t\end{aligned}\]

Given this objective, we see that minimizing \(\eta\) and maximizing \( heta\) are seperatable.

An alternative to parametrizing the distribution path \( ho_t\) is perform minimization of the LOSS via the Wasserstein gradient flow

\[x_t^{\prime}=x_t+\alpha \cdot t(1-t) abla_x\left[ rac{\partial s_t}{\partial t}\left(x_t, heta ight)+K^*\left(s_t\left(x_t, heta ight), t ight)+U\left(s_t\left(x_t, heta ight), t ight) ight]\]

Algorithm

Wassertein-2 Geometry

Definition

Given two densities with finite second moments \(\mu_0, \mu_1 \in \mathcal{P}_2(\mathcal{X})\), the Wassertein-2 OT problem is defined , in the Kantorovich formulation, as a cost-minimization problem over joint distributions \(\pi \in \Pi\left(\mu_0, \mu_1 ight)=\left\{\pi\left(x_0, x_1 ight) \mid \int \pi\left(x_0, x_1 ight) d x_1=\mu_0, \int \pi\left(x_0, x_1 ight) d x_0=\mu_1 ight\}\), i.e.

\[W_2\left(\mu_0, \mu_1 ight)^2:=\inf _{\pi \in \Pi\left(\mu_0, \mu_1 ight)} \int\left \| x_0-x_1 ight \|^2 \pi\left(x_0, x_1 ight) d x_0 d x_1\]

An alternative perspective (dynamical formulation)

An alternative perspective on the \(W_2\) OT problem as an optimization over a vector field \(v_t\) that transports samples according to an ODE \(\dot x_t = v_t\).

The evolution of samples’ density \( ho_t\), under transport by \(v_t\), is governed by the continuity equation \(\dot{ ho}_t = - abla \cdot ( ho_t v_t)\), and we have

\(W_2\left(\mu_0, \mu_1 ight)^2=\inf _{ ho_t} \inf _{v_t} \int_0^1 \int rac{1}{2}\left\| v_t ight \|^2 ho_t d x_t d t \quad\) s.t. \(\dot{ ho}_t=- abla \cdot\left( ho_t v_t ight), \quad ho_0=\mu_0, ho_1=\mu_1\) where \( abla \cdot ()\) is the divergence operator.

The \(W_2\) transport cost can be viewed as providing a Riemannian mannifold structure on the space of densities \(\mathcal{P}_2(\mathcal{X})\)

Wassertein Fisher-Rao Geometry

  • consider additional terms allowing for birth and death of particles

Extending the continuity equation to include a ‘growth term’ \(g_t: \mathcal{X}, ightarrow \mathbb{R}\), the objective is

\[W F R_\lambda\left(\mu_0, \mu_1 ight)^2=\inf _{ ho_t} \inf _{v_t, g_t} \int_0^1 \int\left( rac{1}{2}\left\|v_t ight\|^2+ rac{\lambda}{2} g_t^2 ight) ho_t d x_t d t\]

subject to \(\dot{ ho}_t=- abla \cdot\left( ho_t v_t ight)+\lambda ho_t g_t, ho_0=\mu_0, ho_1=\mu_1\) We call this the Wasserstein Fisher-Rao (WFR) distance, this problem is reffered as unbalanced OT problem

A Riemanian structure on \(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{X})\)

A Riemanian structure on \(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{X})\) via the WFR distance. Introducting Lagrange multipliers \(s_t\) and eliminating \(v_t\), \(g_t\) yields the optimality conditions \(v_t = abla s_t\) and \(g_t = s_t\). This suggests characterizing the tangent space via the tuple \(\left(s_t, abla s_t ight)\) and define the metric as \( egin{aligned} T_ ho^{W F R_\lambda} \mathcal{M}(\mathcal{X}) & =\{\dot{ ho} \mid \dot{ ho}=- abla \cdot( ho abla s)+\lambda ho s\} \ \left\langle\dot{\mu}_t, \dot{ ho}_t ight angle_{T_ ho}^{W F R_\lambda} & =\left\langle s_{\dot{\mu}_t}, s_{\dot{ ho}_t} ight angle_{T_ ho^*}^{W F R_\lambda}=\int\left(\left\langle abla s_{\dot{\mu}_t}, abla s_{\dot{ ho}_t} ight angle+\lambda s_{\dot{\mu}_t} s_{\dot{ ho}_t} ight) ho d x .\end{aligned}\)

Action Matching

The objective is \(\mathcal{A}\left[\mu_t ight]=\sup _{s_t} \int s_1 \mu_1 d x_1-\int s_0 \mu_0 d x_0-\int_0^1 \int\left( rac{\partial s_t}{\partial t}+ rac{1}{2}\left\| abla s_t ight\|^2 ight) \mu_t d x_t d t\) \(s_t: \mathcal{X} imes [0, 1] ightarrow \mathbb{R}\) is parameterized by a neural network, with similar objective for \(WFR_{\lambda}\) we view Action Matching as maximizing a lower bound on the action \(\mathcal{A}[\mu_t]\) or kinetic energy of the curve \(\mu_t : [0, 1] ightarrow \mathcal{P}_2(\mathcal{X})\) of densities. In particular, at those optimal \(s_{\dot{\mu_t}}\) satisfying \(\dot{\mu}_t=- abla \cdot\left(\mu_t abla s_{\dot{\mu}_t} ight)\), \(\mathcal{A}\left[\mu_t ight]=\int_0^1 rac{1}{2}\left\langle\dot{\mu}_t, \dot{\mu}_t ight angle_{T_{\mu_t}}^{W_2} d t=\int_0^1 rac{1}{2}\left\langle s_{\dot{\mu}_t}, s_{\dot{\mu}_t} ight angle_{T_{\mu_t}^*}^{W_2} d t=\int_0^1 \int rac{1}{2}\left\| abla s_t ight\|^2 \mu_t d x_t d t\)

Wassertein Lagrangian Flows

Wassertein Lagrangian and Hamiltonian Flows

\[\mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]=\mathcal{K}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]-\mathcal{U}\left[ ho_t, t ight]\]

define the action of a curve: \(\mathcal{A}( ho_t)=\int_0^1 L\left( ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight) d t\).

seek the action-minimizing curve subject to the constraints:

\[ egin{aligned} \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{L}}\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\}_{i=0}^{M-1} ight) & :=\inf _{ ho_t \in \Gamma\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\} ight)} \mathcal{A}_{\mathcal{L}}\left[ ho_t ight] \ & :=\inf _{ ho_t} \int_0^1 \mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight] d t \quad ext { s.t. } ho_{t_i}=\mu_{t_i} \quad orall 0 \leq i \leq M-1\end{aligned}\]

where \(\Gamma\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\} ight)=\left\{ ho_t:[0,1] ightarrow \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{X}) \mid ho_0=\mu_0, ho_1=\mu_1, ho_{t_i}=\mu_{t_i} \quad( orall 1 \leq i \leq M-2) ight\}\)

Define the Hamiltonian via Legendre transform:

\[\mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]=\sup _{\dot{ ho}_t \in T_{ ho_t} \mathcal{P}} \int \dot{ ho}_t s_t d x_t-\mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]=\mathcal{K}^*\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]+\mathcal{U}\left[ ho_t, t ight]\]

Finally, \(\mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]\) can be written using the Legendre transform \(\mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]=\sup _{s_t \in T_{ ho_t}^* \mathcal{P}} \int \dot{ ho}_t s_t d x_t-\mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]\)

The following theorem forms the basis for our computational approach

Theorem 1. For a Lagrangian \(\mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight]\) which is lsc and strictly convex in \(\dot{ ho}_t\), the optimization

\[\mathcal{S}=\inf _{ ho_t \in \Gamma\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\} ight)} \mathcal{A}_{\mathcal{L}}\left[ ho_t ight]=\inf _{ ho_t \in \Gamma\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\} ight)} \int_0^1 \mathcal{L}\left[ ho_t, \dot{ ho}_t, t ight] d t\]

is equivalent to the following dual

\[\mathcal{S}=\inf _{ ho_t \in \Gamma\left(\left\{\mu_{t_i} ight\} ight)} \sup _{s_t} \int s_1 \mu_1 d x_1-\int s_0 \mu_0 d x_0-\int_0^1\left(\int rac{\partial s_t}{\partial t} ho_t d x_t+\mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight] ight) d t\]

Next, we have Wasserstein Hamiltonian flows satisfy the optimality conditions

\( rac{\partial ho_t}{\partial t}= rac{\delta}{\delta s_t} \mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]\)and \( rac{\partial s_t}{\partial t}=- rac{\delta}{\delta ho_t} \mathcal{H}\left[ ho_t, s_t, t ight]\)

entry.title: Action matching
entry.content:
Action matching: a method for learning population dynamics from samples of their temporal marginals The proposed method can learn dynamics which simulate an arbitrary path of marginal distributions, it can also be applied in the context of generative modeling.

Continuity Equation

any continuous dynamics can be modeled by the continuity equation, and moreover any continuity equation results in a continuous dynamics.

State space to density space

  • Suppose we have a set of particles in space \(\mathcal{X} \subset \mathbb{R}^d\), initially distributed as \(q_{t=0}\). Let each particle follow a timedependent ODE (continuous flow) with the velocity field \(v:[0,1] imes \mathcal{X} ightarrow \mathbb{R}^d\) as follows

    • \[ rac{d}{d t} x(t)=v_t(x(t)), \quad x(t=0)=x\]

    • The continuity equation describes how the density of the particles \(q_t\) evolves in time \(t\), i.e.,

    • \[ rac{\partial}{\partial t} q_t=- abla \cdot\left(q_t v_t ight)\]

Density space to state space

  • Theorem 2.1. Consider a continuous dynamic with the density evolution of \(q_t\), which satisfies mild conditions (absolute continuty in the 2-Wassertein space of distributions \(\mathcal{P}_2(\mathcal{X})\). Then there exists a unique (up to a constant) function \(s_t^*(x)\), called the “action”, such that vector field \(v_t^*(x) = abla s_t^*(x)\) and \(q_t\) satisfies the continuity equation \( rac{\partial}{\partial t} q_t=- abla \cdot\left(q_t abla s_t^*(x) ight)\).

  • In other words, the ODE \( rac{d}{d t} x(t)= abla s_t^*(x)\) can be used to move samples in time such that the marginals are \(q_t\).

  • Using Theorem 2.1, the problem of learning the dynamics can be boiled down to learning the unique vector field \( abla s_t^*\)

  • Based on Theorem 2.1, given density dynamic, we can learn a function \(s_t(x, heta)\) to approximate \(s_t^*\). Then Given \(s_t(x, heta)\), we can calculate the dynamic in the state space.

Action matching

Objective

Recover the true action \(s_t^*\) while having access only to samples from \(q_t\).

The objective is to minimize the “ACTION-GAP” objective \(\operatorname{ACTION-GAP}\left(s, s^* ight):= rac{1}{2} \int_0^1 \mathbb{E}_{q_t(x)}\left\| abla s_t(x)- abla s_t^*(x) ight\|^2 d t\)

Tractable objective

Theorem 2.2. For an arbitrary variational action \(s\), the ACTION-GAP \(\left(s, s^* ight)\) can be decomposed as the sum of an intractable constant \(\mathcal{K}\), and a tractable term \(\mathcal{L}_{A M}(s)\)

\[\operatorname{ACTION-GAP}\left(s_t, s_t^* ight)=\mathcal{K}+\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{AM}}\left(s_t ight) .\]

where \(\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{AM}}(s)\) is the Action Matching objective, which we minimize

\( egin{aligned} \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{AM}}(s) & :=\mathbb{E}_{q_0(x)}\left[s_0(x) ight]-\mathbb{E}_{q_1(x)}\left[s_1(x) ight] \ & +\int_0^1 \mathbb{E}_{q_t(x)}\left[ rac{1}{2}\left\| abla s_t(x) ight\|^2+ rac{\partial s_t}{\partial t}(x) ight] d t \end{aligned}\) The term \(\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{AM}}\) is tractable

Connection with Optimal Transport

The optimal dynamics of AM along the curve is also optimal in the sense of optimal transport with the 2-Wasserstein cost.

the optimal vector field in the AM objective defines a mapping between two infinitesimally close distributions \(q_t\) and \(q_{t+h}\), which is of the form \(x \mapsto x+h abla s_t^*(x)\). This mapping is indeed the same as the Brenier map in optimal transport, which is of the form \(x \mapsto x+h abla \varphi_t(x)\), where \(\varphi_t\) is the (c-convex) Kantorovish potential.

Introduction

Consistency model can be trained in two ways: distilling pre-trained diffusion models, as standalone generative models

Preliminaries

Diffusion models

Let \(p_{ ext{data}}(\mathbf{x})\) denote the data distribution. Diffusion models start by diffusing \(p_{ ext{data}}(x)\) with a stochastic differential equation (SDE) \(\mathrm{d} \mathbf{x}_t= oldsymbol{\mu}\left(\mathbf{x}_t, t ight) \mathrm{d} t+\sigma(t) \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}_t\)

where \(t \in [0, T], T > 0\) is a fixed constant, \(\mu (\cdot, \cdot)\) and \(\sigma(\cdot)\) are the drift and diffusion coefficients respectively, and \(\{ oldsymbol{\omega}_t\}_{t \in [0, T]}\) denotes the standard Brownian motion.

We denote the distribution of \(\mathbf{x}_t\) as \(p_{t}(x)\) and as a result \(p_0(\mathbf{x}) \equiv p_{ ext {data }}(\mathbf{x})\)

the Probability Flow (PF) ODE: \(\mathrm{d} \mathbf{x}_t=\left[ oldsymbol{\mu}\left(\mathbf{x}_t, t ight)- rac{1}{2} \sigma(t)^2 abla \log p_t\left(\mathbf{x}_t ight) ight] \mathrm{d} t\)

We adopt the setting: \( oldsymbol{\mu}(\mathbf{x}, t)=\mathbf{0}\) and \(\sigma(t)=\sqrt{2 t}\), in this case, \(p_t(\mathbf{x})=p_{ ext {data }}(\mathbf{x}) \otimes \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, t^2 oldsymbol{I} ight)\), where \(\otimes\) denotes the convolution operation, and \(\pi(\mathbf{x})=\mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, T^2 oldsymbol{I} ight)\)

For sampling, we first train a score model \( oldsymbol{s}_\phi(\mathbf{x}, t) \approx abla \log p_t(\mathbf{x})\) via score matching, then we have the **empirical PF ODE: **\( rac{\mathrm{d} \mathbf{x}_t}{\mathrm{~d} t}=-t s_\phi\left(\mathbf{x}_t, t ight)\)

To solve this ODE, there are two main ways: numerical ODE solver **and **distillation techniques

EDM Denoiser

Equation 2: \(\mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{y} \sim p_{ ext {data }}} \mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{n} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}\|D( oldsymbol{y}+ oldsymbol{n} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}\|_2^2\)

The optimal analytically solution is \(D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma) = rac{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) oldsymbol{y}_i}{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}\)

Based on Fig. 1, it seems that we cannot get clean image from corrupted image in 1 step.

Preconditioning and training

In practice, instead of parameterize \(D_{ heta}\) directly, we train a different network \(F_{ heta}\) from which \(D_{ heta}\) is derived

\[D_ heta( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)=c_{ ext {skip }}(\sigma) oldsymbol{x}+c_{ ext {out }}(\sigma) F_ heta\left(c_{ ext {in }}(\sigma) oldsymbol{x} ; c_{ ext {noise }}(\sigma) ight)\]

The loss is:

\[\mathbb{E}_{\sigma, oldsymbol{y}, oldsymbol{n}}[\underbrace{\lambda(\sigma) c_{ ext {out }}(\sigma)^2}_{ ext {effective weight }}\|\underbrace{F_ heta\left(c_{ ext {in }}(\sigma) \cdot( oldsymbol{y}+ oldsymbol{n}) ; c_{ ext {noise }}(\sigma) ight)}_{ ext {network output }}-\underbrace{ rac{1}{c_{ ext {out }}(\sigma)}\left( oldsymbol{y}-c_{ ext {skip }}(\sigma) \cdot( oldsymbol{y}+ oldsymbol{n}) ight)}_{ ext {effective training target }}\|_2^2]\]

Consistency Model

What is consistency model

Definition Given a solution trajectory \(\left\{\mathbf{x}_t ight\}_{t \in[\epsilon, T]}\) of the PF ODE\(\mathrm{d} \mathbf{x}_t=\left[ oldsymbol{\mu}\left(\mathbf{x}_t, t ight)- rac{1}{2} \sigma(t)^2 abla \log p_t\left(\mathbf{x}_t ight) ight] \mathrm{d} t\), we define the consistency function as \( oldsymbol{f}:\left(\mathbf{x}_t, t ight) \mapsto \mathbf{x}_\epsilon\). A consistency function has the property of self-consistency: it outputs are consistent for arbitrary pairs of \((\mathbf{x}_t, t)\) that belong to the same PF ODE trajectory, i.e., \( oldsymbol{f}\left(\mathbf{x}_t, t ight)= oldsymbol{f}\left(\mathbf{x}_{t^{\prime}}, t^{\prime} ight)\) for all \(t, t^{\prime} \in[\epsilon, T]\).

self-consistency: points on the same trajectory map to the same initial point.

parameterization

parameterize the consistency model using skip connections:

\[ oldsymbol{f}_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}(\mathbf{x}, t)=c_{ ext {skip }}(t) \mathbf{x}+c_{ ext {out }}(t) F_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}(\mathbf{x}, t)\]

where \(c_{ ext{skip}}(t)\) and \(c_{ ext{out}}(t)\) are differeitiable functions such that \(c_{ ext{skip}}(\epsilon) = 1\) and \(c_{ ext{out}}(\epsilon) = 0\)

The consistency ditillation loss

\[ egin{aligned} \mathcal{L}_{C D}^N\left( oldsymbol{ heta}, oldsymbol{ heta}^{-} ; oldsymbol{\phi} ight) & := \ & \mathbb{E}\left[\lambda\left(t_n ight) d\left( oldsymbol{f}_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{t_{n+1}}, t_{n+1} ight), oldsymbol{f}_{ oldsymbol{ heta}^{-}}\left(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{t_n}^{ oldsymbol{\phi}}, t_n ight) ight) ight]\end{aligned}\]

Background

  • The choice of this inference process affects both likelihoods and sample quality.

  • On different datasets and models, different inference processes work better;

  • A natural question: are there other auxiliary variable diffusions that would lead to improvements like CLD?

  • **Auxiliary variables **have improved other generative models and inferences

    • such as normalizing ﬂows, neural ordinary differential equations (ODEs), hierarchical variational models, ladder variational autoencoder

Requirement of design a diffusion model

  • Selecting an inference and model process pair
    • such that the inference process converges to the model prior

  • Deriving the ELBO for this pair

  • Estimating the ELBO and its gradients
    • by deriving and computing the inference process’ transition kernel

      Work of this paper

  • provide a recipe for training MDMs beyond speciﬁc instantiations to all linear inference processes that have a stationary distribution, with any number of auxiliary variables.

  • Using results from gradient-based Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) to construct MDMs.

  • derive the MDM ELBO.

ELBO bound

Reverse process: \(d \mathbf{z}=h_\theta(\mathbf{z}, t) d t+\beta_\theta(t) d \mathbf{B}_t, \quad t \in[0, T]\)

where \(f_{\phi}, g_{\phi}, s_{\theta}\) are evaluated at \((\mathbf{y}_s, s)\), \(\|\mathbf{x}\|_{\mathbf{A}}^2=\mathbf{x}^{\top} \mathbf{A} \mathbf{x}\) and \(g^2 = gg^T\)

ISM means Implicit Score Matching loss, which can be re-written as an ELBO \(L^{\text{dsm}}\) featuring Denoisng Score Matching (DSM).

Multivariate Model and Inference

\(\mathbf{u}=\left[\begin{array}{c}\mathbf{z}_t \\ \mathbf{v}_t\end{array}\right]\) \(\mathbf{u}_0 \sim \pi_\theta, \quad d \mathbf{u}=h_\theta\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t\right) d t+\beta_\theta(t) d \mathbf{B}_t\)

entry.content:
Ideas

  • The diffusion process is the key to improve synthesis quality or** sampling speed**.

  • Inspired by statistical mechanics.

  • The score of the conditional distribution \(p_t( oldsymbol{v}_t \vert oldsymbol{x}_t)\) is an arguably easier task than learning the score of \(p_t( oldsymbol{x}_t)\).

Background

  • The forward process: \(d \mathbf{u}_t= oldsymbol{f}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight) d t+ oldsymbol{G}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight) d \mathbf{w}_t, \quad t \in[0, T]\)

  • The backward process: \(d \overline{\mathbf{u}}_t=\left[- oldsymbol{f}\left(\overline{\mathbf{u}}_t, T-t ight)+ oldsymbol{G}\left(\overline{\mathbf{u}}_t, T-t ight) oldsymbol{G}\left(\overline{\mathbf{u}}_t, T-t ight)^{ op} abla_{\overline{\mathbf{u}}_t} \log p_{T-t}\left(\overline{\mathbf{u}}_t ight) ight] d t+ oldsymbol{G}\left(\overline{\mathbf{u}}_t, T-t ight) d \mathbf{w}_t\)

  • Currently used SDEs have drift and diffusion coefficients of the symple form: \( oldsymbol{f}\left(\mathbf{x}_t, t ight)=f(t) \mathbf{x}_t\) and \( oldsymbol{G}\left(\mathbf{x}_t, t ight)=g(t) oldsymbol{I}_d\)

  • Generally, setting \(p\left(\mathbf{u}_0 ight)=p_{ ext {data }}(\mathbf{x})\), \(p\left(\mathbf{u}_T ight)= \mathcal{N}( oldsymbol{0}, oldsymbol{I}_d)\).

  • If \( oldsymbol{f}\) and \( oldsymbol{G}\) take the simple form above, the denoising score matching objective is: \(\min _{ oldsymbol{ heta}} \mathbb{E}_{t \sim \mathcal{U}[0, T]} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}_0 \sim p\left(\mathbf{x}_0 ight)} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}_t \sim p_t\left(\mathbf{x}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0 ight)}\left[\lambda(t)\left\|\mathbf{s}_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left(\mathbf{x}_t, t ight)- abla_{\mathbf{x}_t} \log p_t\left(\mathbf{x}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0 ight) ight\|_2^2 ight]\)

  • If \( oldsymbol{f}\) and \( oldsymbol{G}\) are affine, the conditional distribution \(p_t\left(\mathbf{x}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0 ight)\) is Normal and avaiable analytically.

Critically-damped Langevin Dynamic

  • We propose to augment the data \(\mathbf{x}_t \in \mathbb{R}^d\) and \(\mathbf{v}_t \in \mathbb{R}^d\). With \(\mathbf{u}_t=\left(\mathbf{x}_t, \mathbf{v}_t ight)^{ op} \in \mathbb{R}^{2 d}\), we set
  • \[ oldsymbol{f}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight):=\left(\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & eta M^{-1} \ - eta & -\Gamma eta M^{-1}\end{array} ight) \otimes oldsymbol{I}_d ight) \mathbf{u}_t, \quad oldsymbol{G}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight):=\left( egin{array}{cc}0 & 0 \ 0 & \sqrt{2 \Gamma eta}\end{array} ight) \otimes oldsymbol{I}_d\]

  • The coupled SDE that describes the diffusion process: \(\left( egin{array}{l}d \mathbf{x}_t \ d \mathbf{v}_t\end{array} ight)=\underbrace{\left( egin{array}{c}M^{-1} \mathbf{v}_t \ -\mathbf{x}_t\end{array} ight) eta d t}_{ ext {Hamiltonian component }=: H}+\underbrace{\left( egin{array}{c}\mathbf{0}_d \ -\Gamma M^{-1} \mathbf{v}_t\end{array} ight) eta d t+\left( egin{array}{c}0 \ \sqrt{2 \Gamma eta}\end{array} ight) d \mathbf{w}_t}_{ ext {Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process=:O }}\)

  • The mass \(M \in \mathbb{R}^+\) is a hyperparameter that determines the coupling between the \(\mathbf{x}_t\)and \(\mathbf{v}_t\) variables.

  • \( eta \in \mathbb{R}^+\) is a constant time rescaling chosen such that the diffusion converges to its equilibrium distribution (we found constant \( eta\)’s to work well).

  • \(\Gamma \in \mathbb{R}^+\) is a friction coefficient that determines the strength of the noise injection into the velocities.

  • The Hamiltonian component plays a role to accelerate sampling and efﬁciently explore complex probability distributions.

  • The \(O\) term corresponds to an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process in the velocity, which injects noise such that the diffusion dynamics properly converge to equilibrium for any \(\Gamma > 0\).

  • It can be shown that the equilibrium distribution of this diffusion is \(p_{\mathrm{EQ}}(\mathbf{u})=\mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{x} ; \mathbf{0}_d, oldsymbol{I}_d ight) \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{v} ; \mathbf{0}_d, M oldsymbol{I}_d ight)\)

  • The balance between \(M\) and \(\Gamma\)

    • For \(\Gamma^2 < 4M\)(underdamped Langevin dynamics): oscillatory dynamics of \(\mathbf{x}_t\) and \( oldsymbol{v}_t\) that slow down converge to equilibrium.

    • For \(\Gamma^2 > 4M\)(overdamped Langevin dynamics): the \(O\) term dominates wihci also slows down convergence.

    • For \(\Gamma^2 = 4M\)(critically-damped Langevin dynamics): an ideal balance is achieved and convergence to \(p_{\mathrm{EQ}}(\mathbf{u})\) as fast as possible in a smooth manner without oscillations.

Score Matching Objective

  • we initialize the joint \( ar{p}\left(\mathbf{u}_0 ight)=p\left(\mathbf{x}_0 ight) p\left(\mathbf{v}_0 ight)=p_{ ext {data }}\left(\mathbf{x}_0 ight) \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{v}_0 ; \mathbf{0}_d, \gamma M oldsymbol{I}_d ight)\) with hyperparameter \(\gamma < 1\)

  • let the distribution diffuse towards the tractable equilibrium—or prior—distribution \(p_{\mathrm{EQ}}(\mathbf{u})\).

  • The score matching (SM) objective: \(\min _{ oldsymbol{ heta}} \mathbb{E}_{t \sim \mathcal{U}[0, T]} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{u}_t \sim p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t ight)}\left[\lambda(t)\left\|s_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight)- abla_{\mathbf{v}_t} \log p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t ight) ight\|_2^2 ight]\)

  • \[ abla_{\mathbf{v}_t} \log p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t ight)= abla_{\mathbf{v}_t}\left[\log p_t\left(\mathbf{v}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_t ight)+\log p_t\left(\mathbf{x}_t ight) ight]= abla_{\mathbf{v}_t} \log p_t\left(\mathbf{v}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_t ight)\]

  • Why \(p_t\left(\mathbf{v}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_t ight)\) is eaiser to learn

    • our velocity distribution is initialized from a simple Normal distribution, such that \(p_t\left(\mathbf{v}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_t ight)\) is closer to a Normal distribution for all \(t \geq 0\) than \(p_t\left( \mathbf{x}_t ight)\) itself.

    • empirically verify the reduced complexity

Hybrid score matching

  • Objective: \(\min _{ oldsymbol{ heta}} \mathbb{E}_{t \in[0, T]} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}_0 \sim p_0\left(\mathbf{x}_0 ight)} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{u}_t \sim p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0 ight)}\left[\lambda(t)\left\|s_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight)- abla_{\mathbf{v}_t} \log p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0 ight) ight\|_2^2 ight]\)

Score Model Parameterization

  • \(\mathbf{u}_t= oldsymbol{\mu}_t\left(\mathbf{x}_0 ight)+ oldsymbol{L}_t oldsymbol{\epsilon}_{2 d}\), where \( oldsymbol{\Sigma}_t= oldsymbol{L}_t oldsymbol{L}_t^{ op}\) is the Cholesky decomposition of \(p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0 ight)\)’s covariance matrix, \( oldsymbol{\epsilon}_{2 d} \sim \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{\epsilon}_{2 d} ; \mathbf{0}_{2 d}, oldsymbol{I}_{2 d} ight)\), and \( oldsymbol{\mu}_t\left(\mathbf{x}_0 ight)\) is \(p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0 ight)\)’s mean.
  • \[ abla_{\mathbf{v}_t} \log p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0 ight)=-\ell_t oldsymbol{\epsilon}_{d: 2 d}\]

  • With \( oldsymbol{\Sigma}_t=\underbrace{\left( egin{array}{cc}\Sigma_t^{x x} & \Sigma_t^{x v} \ \Sigma_t^{x v} & \Sigma_t^{v v}\end{array} ight)}_{ ext {"per-dimension" covariance matrix }} \otimes oldsymbol{I}_d, \quad\) we have \(\quad \ell_t:=\sqrt{ rac{\Sigma_t^{x x}}{\Sigma_t^{x x} \Sigma_t^{v v}-\left(\Sigma_t^{x v} ight)^2}}\)

  • We parameterize \(s_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight)=-\ell_t \alpha_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight)\) with \(\alpha_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight)=\ell_t^{-1} \mathbf{v}_t / \Sigma_t^{v v}+ \alpha'_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight)\), where \(\Sigma_t^{vv}\) corresponds to the \(v-v\) component of the “per-dimension” covariance matrix of the Normal Distribution \(p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0=\mathbf{0}_d ight)\)

  • \[\operatorname{HSM}(\lambda(t))=\mathbb{E}_{t \sim \mathcal{U}[0, T], \mathbf{x}_0 \sim p_0\left(\mathbf{x}_0 ight), \mathbf{u}_t \sim p_t\left(\mathbf{u}_t \mid \mathbf{x}_0 ight)}\left[\lambda(t)\left(\ell_t^{\mathrm{HSM}} ight)^2\left\| oldsymbol{\epsilon}_{d: 2 d}-\alpha_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left(\mathbf{u}_t, t ight) ight\|_2^2 ight]\]
  • Training objective: \(\min _{ oldsymbol{ heta}} \mathbb{E}_{t \sim \mathcal{U}[0, T]} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x}_0 \sim p_0\left(\mathbf{x}_0 ight)} \mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{\epsilon}_{2 d} \sim \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{\epsilon}_{2 d} ; \mathbf{0}_{2 d}, oldsymbol{I}_{2 d} ight)}\left[\lambda(t) \ell_t^2\left\| oldsymbol{\epsilon}_{d: 2 d}-\alpha_{ oldsymbol{ heta}}\left( oldsymbol{\mu}_t\left(\mathbf{x}_0 ight)+ oldsymbol{L}_t oldsymbol{\epsilon}_{2 d}, t ight) ight\|_2^2 ight]\)

link.title: Elucidating the Design Space of Diffusion-Based Generative Models

entry.content:
Original ODE / SDE formulation from previous work

  • Song et al. define their forward SDE as: \(dx = f(x,t)dt + g(t) dw_t\), where \(f(\cdot, t):\mathbb{R}^d ightarrow \mathbb{R}^d\)and \(g(\cdot): \mathbb{R} ightarrow \mathbb{R}\)are the drift and diffusion coefficients, repsectively, where \(d\)is the dimensionality of the dataset. \(f(\cdot)\)is always of the form

\(f(x, t) = f(t) x\), where \(f(\cdot):\mathbb{R} ightarrow \mathbb{R}.\)

  • Thus, the SDE can be equivalently written as\(dx = f(t)x + g(t) d w_t\).

  • The pertubation kernels of this SDE have the general form \(p_{0t}(x(t) \vert x(0)) = \mathcal{N} (x(t); s(t)x(0), s^2(t) \sigma^2(t)\mathbf{I})\),

  • where \(\mathcal{N}(x; \mu, \Sigma)\)denotes the probability density function of \(\mathcal{N}(\mu, \Sigma)\)evaluated at \(x\),

\[s(t)=\exp \left(\int_0^t f(\xi) \mathrm{d} \xi ight), \quad ext { and } \quad \sigma(t)=\sqrt{\int_0^t rac{g(\xi)^2}{s(\xi)^2} \mathrm{~d} \xi}\]
  • The marginal distribution of \(p_t(x)\)is
\[p_t( oldsymbol{x})=\int_{\mathbb{R}^d} p_{0 t}\left( oldsymbol{x} \mid oldsymbol{x}_0 ight) p_{ ext {data }}\left( oldsymbol{x}_0 ight) \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_0\]
  • The probability flow ODE
\[\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}=\left[f(t) oldsymbol{x}- rac{1}{2} g(t)^2 abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p_t( oldsymbol{x}) ight] \mathrm{d} t .\]

Understanding the diffusion process

Idea

\(f\)and \(g\)are of little practical interest, the marginal distribution are of utmost inportance

The perturbation kernels and marginal distribution

\[p_{0 t}( oldsymbol{x}(t) \mid oldsymbol{x}(0))=\mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x}(t) ; s(t) oldsymbol{x}(0), s(t)^2 \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\] \[p_t( oldsymbol{x})=\int_{\mathbb{R}^d} p_{0 t}\left( oldsymbol{x} \mid oldsymbol{x}_0 ight) p_{ ext {data }}\left( oldsymbol{x}_0 ight) \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_0\]

Convolution form

\(p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma) :=p_{ ext {data }} * \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}, \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I})\) \(p_t( oldsymbol{x})=s(t)^{-d} p( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; \sigma(t))\)

ODE

\(\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}=-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma(t)) \mathrm{d} t\)

\[\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}=\left[ rac{\dot{ oldsymbol{s}}(t)}{s(t)} oldsymbol{x}-s(t)^2 \dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p\left( rac{ oldsymbol{x}}{s(t)} ; \sigma(t) ight) ight] \mathrm{d} t\]

Denosing score matching

\(D( oldsymbol{x}; \sigma)\)is a denoiser function that minimizes the expeced \(L_2\)denosing error for samples drawn from \(p_{ ext{data}}\),

\(\mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{y} \sim p_{ ext {data }}} \mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{n} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}\|D( oldsymbol{y}+ oldsymbol{n} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}\|_2^2\), then \( abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)=(D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{x}) / \sigma^2\)

Heat equation

$$\left{ egin{matrix}

& rac{\partial q}{\partial t} -\dot{\sigma} \sigma \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q = 0 & ext{in} \quad \mathbb{R}^d imes(0, \, \infty) \ &q= p_{data}( oldsymbol{x}) & ext{on} \quad \mathbb{R}^d imes {t=0}

\end{matrix} ight.$$

SDE

\(\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}=\left( rac{1}{2} g(t)^2-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) ight) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma(t)) \mathrm{d} t+g(t) \mathrm{d} \omega_t\)

\[\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_{ \pm}=\underbrace{-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma(t)) \mathrm{d} t}_{ ext {probability flow ODE}} \pm \underbrace{ eta(t) \sigma(t)^2 abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma(t)) \mathrm{d} t}_{ ext {deterministic noise decay }}+\underbrace{\sqrt{2 eta(t)} \sigma(t) \mathrm{d} \omega_t}_{ ext {noise injection }}\]

ODE formulation

Equation 1: \(\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}=-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma(t)) \mathrm{d} t\)

Proof

The marginal distrobution

\[ egin{aligned} p_t( oldsymbol{x}) & =\int_{\mathbb{R}^d} p_{0 t}\left( oldsymbol{x} \mid oldsymbol{x}_0 ight) p_{ ext {data }}\left( oldsymbol{x}_0 ight) \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_0 \ & =\int_{\mathbb{R}^d} p_{ ext {data }}\left( oldsymbol{x}_0 ight)\left[\mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; s(t) oldsymbol{x}_0, s(t)^2 \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I} ight) ight] \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_0 \ & =\int_{\mathbb{R}^d} p_{ ext {data }}\left( oldsymbol{x}_0 ight)\left[s(t)^{-d} \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; oldsymbol{x}_0, \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I} ight) ight] \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_0 \ & =s(t)^{-d} \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} p_{ ext {data }}\left( oldsymbol{x}_0 ight) \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; oldsymbol{x}_0, \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I} ight) \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_0 \ & =s(t)^{-d}\left[p_{ ext {data }} * \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I} ight) ight]( oldsymbol{x} / s(t)), \end{aligned}\]

where \(p_a * p_b\)denotes the convolution of probability density functions \(p_a\)and \(p_b\)

Let denote:

\[p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)=p_{ ext {data }} * \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I} ight) \quad ext { and } \quad p_t( oldsymbol{x})=s(t)^{-d} p( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; \sigma(t))\]

the probability ﬂow ODE

\[ egin{aligned} \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x} & =\left[f(t) oldsymbol{x}- rac{1}{2} g(t)^2 abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log \left[p_t( oldsymbol{x}) ight] ight] \mathrm{d} t \ & =\left[f(t) oldsymbol{x}- rac{1}{2} g(t)^2 abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log \left[s(t)^{-d} p( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; \sigma(t)) ight] ight] \mathrm{d} t \ & =\left[f(t) oldsymbol{x}- rac{1}{2} g(t)^2\left[ abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log s(t)^{-d}+ abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; \sigma(t)) ight] ight] \mathrm{d} t \ & =\left[f(t) oldsymbol{x}- rac{1}{2} g(t)^2 abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; \sigma(t)) ight] \mathrm{d} t . \end{aligned}\]

Next, \(f(t) = {\dot s(t)}/{s(t)}\), \(g(t) = s(t) \sqrt{2 \dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t)}\)

\[ egin{aligned} \exp \left(\int_0^t f(\xi) \mathrm{d} \xi ight) & =s(t) \ \int_0^t f(\xi) \mathrm{d} \xi & =\log s(t) \ \mathrm{d}\left[\int_0^t f(\xi) \mathrm{d} \xi ight] / \mathrm{d} t & =\mathrm{d}[\log s(t)] / \mathrm{d} t \ f(t) & =\dot{s}(t) / s(t) . \end{aligned}\] \[ egin{aligned} \sqrt{\int_0^t rac{g(\xi)^2}{s(\xi)^2} \mathrm{~d} \xi} & =\sigma(t) \ \int_0^t rac{g(\xi)^2}{s(\xi)^2} \mathrm{~d} \xi & =\sigma(t)^2 \ \mathrm{~d}\left[\int_0^t rac{g(\xi)^2}{s(\xi)^2} \mathrm{~d} \xi ight] / \mathrm{d} t & =\mathrm{d}\left[\sigma(t)^2 ight] / \mathrm{d} t \ g(t)^2 / s(t)^2 & =2 \dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) \ g(t) / s(t) & =\sqrt{2 \dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t)} \ g(t) & =s(t) \sqrt{2 \dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t)} . \end{aligned}\]

Finally

\[ egin{aligned} \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x} & =\left[[f(t)] oldsymbol{x}- rac{1}{2}[g(t)]^2 abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; \sigma(t)) ight] \mathrm{d} t \ & =\left[[\dot{s}(t) / s(t)] oldsymbol{x}- rac{1}{2}[s(t) \sqrt{2 \dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t)}]^2 abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; \sigma(t)) ight] \mathrm{d} t \ & =\left[[\dot{s}(t) / s(t)] oldsymbol{x}- rac{1}{2}\left[2 s(t)^2 \dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) ight] abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; \sigma(t)) ight] \mathrm{d} t \ & =\left[ rac{\dot{s}(t)}{s(t)} oldsymbol{x}-s(t)^2 \dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p\left( rac{ oldsymbol{x}}{s(t)} ; \sigma(t) ight) ight] \mathrm{d} t \end{aligned}\]

By setting \(s(t) = 1\):

\[\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}=-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma(t)) \mathrm{d} t\]

Denoising score matching

Equation 2 & 3

\(\mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{y} \sim p_{ ext {data }}} \mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{n} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}\|D( oldsymbol{y}+ oldsymbol{n} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}\|_2^2\), then \( abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)=(D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{x}) / \sigma^2\)

Proof

Finite number of samples \(\{\mathbf{y}_1, \cdots, \mathbf{y}_Y \}\),\(p_{data}(x)\)is represented by a mixture of Dirac delta distributions:\(p_{ ext{data}}(x) = rac{1}{Y} \sum_{i=1}^{Y} \delta(\mathbf{x} - \mathbf{y}_i)\)

\[ egin{aligned} p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma) & =p_{ ext {data }} * \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I} ight) \ & =\int_{\mathbb{R}^d} p_{ ext {data }}\left( oldsymbol{x}_0 ight) \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{x}_0, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_0 \ & =\int_{\mathbb{R}^d}\left[ rac{1}{Y} \sum_{i=1}^Y \delta\left( oldsymbol{x}_0- oldsymbol{y}_i ight) ight] \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{x}_0, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_0 \ & = rac{1}{Y} \sum_{i=1}^Y \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{x}_0, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) \delta\left( oldsymbol{x}_0- oldsymbol{y}_i ight) \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}_0 \ & = rac{1}{Y} \sum_{i=1}^Y \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\end{aligned}\]

Considering the Eq. 2. by expanding the expections:

\[ egin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(D ; \sigma) & =\mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{y} \sim p_{ ext {data }}} \mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{n} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}\|D( oldsymbol{y}+ oldsymbol{n} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}\|_2^2 \ & =\mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{y} \sim p_{ ext {data }}} \mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{x} \sim \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{y}, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}\|D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}\|_2^2 \ & =\mathbb{E}_{ oldsymbol{y} \sim p_{ ext {data }}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\|D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}\|_2^2 \mathrm{~d} oldsymbol{x} \ & = rac{1}{Y} \sum_{i=1}^Y \int_{\mathbb{R}^d} \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\left\|D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}_i ight\|_2^2 \mathrm{~d} oldsymbol{x} \ & =\int_{\mathbb{R}^d} \underbrace{ rac{1}{Y} \sum_{i=1}^Y \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\left\|D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}_i ight\|_2^2}_{=: \mathcal{L}(D ; oldsymbol{x}, \sigma)} \mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x} .\end{aligned}\]

we can minimize \(\mathcal{L}(D ; \sigma)\)by minimizing $$\mathcal{L}(D ; oldsymbol{x}, \sigma)

\(independently for each\) oldsymbol{x}$$:

\(D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)=\arg \min _{D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)} \mathcal{L}(D ; oldsymbol{x}, \sigma)\) This is a convex optimization problem; its solution is uniquely identiﬁed by setting the gradient w.r.t. \(D( oldsymbol{x}; \sigma)\)to zero:

\[ egin{aligned} \mathbf{0} & = abla_{D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)}[\mathcal{L}(D ; oldsymbol{x}, \sigma)] \ \mathbf{0} & = abla_{D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)}\left[ rac{1}{Y} \sum_{i=1}^Y \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\left\|D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}_i ight\|_2^2 ight] \ \mathbf{0} & =\sum_{i=1}^Y \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) abla_{D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)}\left[\left\|D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{y}_i ight\|_2^2 ight] \ \mathbf{0} & =\sum_{i=1}^Y \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\left[2 D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)-2 oldsymbol{y}_i ight] \ \mathbf{0} & =\left[\sum_{i=1}^Y \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) ight] D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)-\sum_{i=1}^Y \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) oldsymbol{y}_i \ D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma) & = rac{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) oldsymbol{y}_i}{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}\end{aligned}\]

which gives a closed-form solution for the ideal denoiser \(D( oldsymbol{x}; \sigma)\).

\[D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma) = rac{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) oldsymbol{y}_i}{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}\]

Next, let us consider the score of the distribution

\[ egin{aligned} abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma) & = rac{ abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)}{p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)} \ & = rac{ abla_{ oldsymbol{x}}\left[ rac{1}{Y} \sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) ight]}{\left[ rac{1}{Y} \sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) ight]} \ & = rac{\sum_i abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}\end{aligned}\]

Then

\[ egin{aligned} abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) & = abla_{ oldsymbol{x}}\left[\left(2 \pi \sigma^2 ight)^{- rac{d}{2}} \exp rac{\left\| oldsymbol{x}- oldsymbol{y}_i ight\|_2^2}{-2 \sigma^2} ight] \ & =\left(2 \pi \sigma^2 ight)^{- rac{d}{2}} abla_{ oldsymbol{x}}\left[\exp rac{\left\| oldsymbol{x}- oldsymbol{y}_i ight\|_2^2}{-2 \sigma^2} ight] \ & =\left[\left(2 \pi \sigma^2 ight)^{- rac{d}{2}} \exp rac{\left\| oldsymbol{x}- oldsymbol{y}_i ight\|_2^2}{-2 \sigma^2} ight] abla_{ oldsymbol{x}}\left[ rac{\left\| oldsymbol{x}- oldsymbol{y}_i ight\|_2^2}{-2 \sigma^2} ight] \ & =\mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}}\left[ rac{\left\| oldsymbol{x}- oldsymbol{y}_i ight\|_2^2}{-2 \sigma^2} ight] \ & =\mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\left[ rac{ oldsymbol{y}_i- oldsymbol{x}}{\sigma^2} ight] .\end{aligned}\]

Next

\[ egin{aligned} abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma) & = rac{\sum_i abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)} \ & = rac{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\left[ rac{ oldsymbol{y}_i- oldsymbol{x}}{\sigma^2} ight]}{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)} \ & =\left( rac{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight) oldsymbol{y}_i}{\sum_i \mathcal{N}\left( oldsymbol{x} ; oldsymbol{y}_i, \sigma^2 \mathbf{I} ight)}- oldsymbol{x} ight) / \sigma^2 .\end{aligned}\]

So \( abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)=(D( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)- oldsymbol{x}) / \sigma^2\)

Proposed SDE

Task 1: Find a PDE given initial value \(q( oldsymbol{x}, 0):= p_{data}( oldsymbol{x})\), and solution \(q( oldsymbol{x}, t) = p( oldsymbol{x}, \sigma(t))\)

The solution is a heat equation

\[ rac{\partial q( oldsymbol{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t)\]

Proof

\(p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma)=p_{ ext {data }} * \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\) and \(p_t( oldsymbol{x})=s(t)^{-d} p( oldsymbol{x} / s(t) ; \sigma(t))\)

the density evolves according to a heat diffusion PDE with time-varying diffusivity. As a ﬁrst step, we ﬁnd this PDE.

The solution can be generated by the heat equation with time-varying diffusivity \(\kappa(t)\).

The heat equation PDE:

\[ rac{\partial \hat{q}( oldsymbol{ u}, t)}{\partial t}=-\kappa(t)| oldsymbol{ u}|^2 \hat{q}( oldsymbol{ u}, t)\]

Take Fourier transform along the \( oldsymbol{x}- ext{dimension}\)

\[ rac{\partial \hat{q}( oldsymbol{ u}, t)}{\partial t}=-\kappa(t)| oldsymbol{ u}|^2 \hat{q}( oldsymbol{ u}, t)\]

Since \(q( oldsymbol{x}, t)=p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma(t))=p_{ ext {data }}( oldsymbol{x}) * \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma(t)^2 \mathbf{I} ight)\), \(\hat{q}( oldsymbol{ u}, t)=\hat{p}_{ ext {data }}( oldsymbol{ u}) \exp \left(- rac{1}{2}| oldsymbol{ u}|^2 \sigma(t)^2 ight)\)

Differentiating the target solution along the time axis, we have

\( egin{aligned} rac{\partial \hat{q}( oldsymbol{ u}, t)}{\partial t} & =-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t)| oldsymbol{ u}|^2 \hat{p}_{ ext {data }}( oldsymbol{ u}) \exp \left(- rac{1}{2}| oldsymbol{ u}|^2 \sigma(t)^2 ight) \ & =-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t)| oldsymbol{ u}|^2 \hat{q}( oldsymbol{ u}, t)\end{aligned}\) Then we have

\[ egin{aligned}-\kappa(t)| oldsymbol{ u}|^2 \hat{q}( oldsymbol{ u}, t) & =-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t)| oldsymbol{ u}|^2 \hat{q}( oldsymbol{ u}, t) \ \kappa(t) & =\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) .\end{aligned}\]

To summzrize

\[ rac{\partial q( oldsymbol{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t)\]

Task 2: Seek an SDE whose solution density is described by the PDE \( rac{\partial q( oldsymbol{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t)\)

Solution: \(\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}=\left( rac{1}{2} g(t)^2-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) ight) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma(t)) \mathrm{d} t+g(t) \mathrm{d} \omega_t\)

Proof

Given an SDE,\(\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}= oldsymbol{f}( oldsymbol{x}, t) \mathrm{d} t+ oldsymbol{g}( oldsymbol{x}, t) \mathrm{d} \omega_t\), The Fokker–Planck PDE describes the time evolution of its solution probability density \(r( oldsymbol{x},t)\) as

\[ rac{\partial r( oldsymbol{x}, t)}{\partial t}=- abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \cdot( oldsymbol{f}( oldsymbol{x}, t) r( oldsymbol{x}, t))+ rac{1}{2} abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} abla_{ oldsymbol{x}}:(\mathbf{D}( oldsymbol{x}, t) r( oldsymbol{x}, t))\]

where \(\mathbf{D}_{i j}=\sum_k oldsymbol{g}_{i k} oldsymbol{g}_{j k}\) is diffusion tensor. We consider a special case \( oldsymbol{g}( oldsymbol{x}, t) = g(t) oldsymbol{I}\)

\[ rac{\partial r( oldsymbol{x}, t)}{\partial t}=- abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \cdot( oldsymbol{f}( oldsymbol{x}, t) r( oldsymbol{x}, t))+ rac{1}{2} g(t)^2 \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} r( oldsymbol{x}, t)\]

We can find a sufﬁcient condition that sastify the PDE \( rac{\partial q( oldsymbol{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t)\)

\[- abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \cdot( oldsymbol{f}( oldsymbol{x}, t) q( oldsymbol{x}, t))+ rac{1}{2} g(t)^2 \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t) = \dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t)\]

The key is given by the identity \( abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \cdot abla_{ oldsymbol{x}}=\Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}}\). We set \( oldsymbol{f}( oldsymbol{x}, t) q( oldsymbol{x}, t)=v(t) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t)\), then

\[ egin{aligned} abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \cdot\left(v(t) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t) ight) & =\left( rac{1}{2} g(t)^2-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) ight) \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t) \ v(t) \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t) & =\left( rac{1}{2} g(t)^2-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) ight) \Delta_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t) \ v(t) & = rac{1}{2} g(t)^2-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) .\end{aligned}\]

\( oldsymbol{f}( oldsymbol{x}, t)\)is in fact proportional to the score function:

\[ egin{aligned} oldsymbol{f}( oldsymbol{x}, t) & =v(t) rac{ abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} q( oldsymbol{x}, t)}{q( oldsymbol{x}, t)} \ & =v(t) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log q( oldsymbol{x}, t) \ & =\left( rac{1}{2} g(t)^2-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) ight) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log q( oldsymbol{x}, t)\end{aligned}\]

we recover a family of SDEs whose solution densities have the desired marginals with noise levels \(\sigma(t)\) for any choice of \(g(t)\):

\[\mathrm{d} oldsymbol{x}=\left( rac{1}{2} g(t)^2-\dot{\sigma}(t) \sigma(t) ight) abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \log p( oldsymbol{x} ; \sigma(t)) \mathrm{d} t+g(t) \mathrm{d} \omega_t\]

entry.title: Generative Modeling by Estimating Gradients of the Data Distribution

link.title: Generative Modeling by Estimating Gradients of the Data Distribution

entry.content:
Gradients can be ill-deﬁned and hard to estimate when the data resides on low-dimensional manifolds.

Two ingredients: score matching and Langevin dynamics

Since Langevin dynamics will often be initialized in low-density regions of the data distribution, inaccurate score estimation in these regions will negatively affect the sampling process.

In practice, this analysis also holds when different modes have approximately disjoint supports—they may share the same support but be connected by regions of small data density.

Score matching

The diffusion model uses energy-based models: : \(p_ heta(\mathbf{x})= rac{e^{f_ heta(\mathbf{x})}}{Z( heta)}\) Score function: \(s_{ heta}( extbf{x}) = abla_\mathbf{x} \log p_ heta(\mathbf{x})\)

The goal of score-based model:

\[ egin{equation*} \mathbf{s}_ heta (\mathbf{x}) = abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_ heta (\mathbf{x} ) = abla_{\mathbf{x}} f_ heta (\mathbf{x}) - \underbrace{ abla_\mathbf{x} \log Z_ heta}_{=0} = abla_\mathbf{x} f_ heta(\mathbf{x}). \end{equation*}\]

Minimize the Fisher divergence, or simply the MSE: \(\mathcal{L}_{mse} = \mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}} \left[ rac{1}{2} \left\lVert s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}) - abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_{ ext{data}}(\mathbf{x}) ight\lVert_2^2 ight]\)

However, Fisher divergence is not directly computable, the real \( abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_{ ext{data}}(\mathbf{x})\) is usually unknown.

To simply discussion, consider 1-D random variables:

\[ egin{aligned} \mathcal{L}_{mse} = & rac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}}\left[\left( abla_x \log p_{ ext {data }}(x)- abla_x \log p_ heta(x) ight)^2 ight] \ = & rac{1}{2} \int p_{ ext {data }}(x)\left( abla_x \log p_{ ext {data }}(x)- abla_x \log p_ heta(x) ight)^2 \mathrm{~d} x \ = & \underbrace{ rac{1}{2} \int p_{ ext {data }}(x)\left( abla_x \log p_{ ext {data }}(x) ight)^2 \mathrm{~d} x}_{ ext {const }}+ rac{1}{2} \int p_{ ext {data }}(x)\left( abla_x \log p_ heta(x) ight)^2 \mathrm{~d} x \ & -\int p_{ ext {data }}(x) abla_x \log p_ heta(x) abla_x \log p_{ ext {data }}(x) \mathrm{d} x .\end{aligned}\]

The objective can be written in 3 terms, the first term is a constant, the second term is easy to calculate, next we handle the thirt term by integration by parts:

\[ egin{aligned} &-\int p_{ ext {data }}(x) abla_x \log p_ heta(x) abla_x \log p_{ ext {data }}(x) \mathrm{d} x \ &=-\int abla_x \log p_ heta(x) abla_x p_{ ext {data }}(x) \mathrm{d} x \ &=-\left.p_{ ext {data }}(x) abla_x \log p_ heta(x) ight|_{-\infty} ^{\infty}+\int p_{ ext {data }}(x) abla_x^2 \log p_ heta(x) \mathrm{d} x \ & \stackrel{(i)}{=} \mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}}\left[ abla_x^2 \log p_ heta(x) ight]\end{aligned}\]

where \((i)\)holds if we assume \(p_{ ext{data}}(x) ightarrow 0\)where \(|x| ightarrow 0\). Now, \( egin{aligned} & rac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}}\left[\left( abla_x \log p_{ ext {data }}(x)- abla_x \log p_ heta(x) ight)^2 ight] \ = & \mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}}\left[ abla_x^2 \log p_ heta(x) ight]+ rac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}}\left[\left( abla_x \log p_ heta(x) ight)^2 ight]+ ext { const. }\end{aligned}\)

Generalizing the integration by parts to multi-dimentsional data, the minimum of \(\mathcal{L}_{mse}\) can be found through a tractable objective:

\(\mathcal{L}_{matching} = \mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}} \left[ ext{ tr}\left( abla_{\mathbf{x}} s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}) ight) + rac{1}{2} \left\Vert s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}) ight\lVert_2^2 ight]\) where \( abla_{\mathbf{x}} s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x})\) denotes the Jacobian of \(s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x})\) with respect to \(\mathbf{x}\), and \( ext{tr}(\cdot)\) is the trace operation.

Cons: the computation of\( ext{ tr}\left( abla_{\mathbf{x}} s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}) ight)\)is a \(O(N^2+N)\), thus not being suitable for high-dimensional problems.

Sliced score matching

Idea: one dimensional data distribution is much easier to estimate for score matching.

We denote \(\mathbf{v}\)as the random projection direction, and \(p_\mathbf{v}\)as its distribution. The random projected version of Fisher divergence is:

\( rac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}}\left[\left(\mathbf{v}^{ op} abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_{ ext {data }}(\mathbf{x})-\mathbf{v}^{ op} abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_ heta(\mathbf{x}) ight)^2 ight]\) which we name as the sliced Fisher divergence. Therefore play the same trick of integration by parts to obatain the following tractable form:

  • \[\mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}}\left[\mathbf{v}^{ op} abla_{\mathbf{x}}^2 \log p_ heta(\mathbf{x}) \mathbf{v}+ rac{1}{2}\left(\mathbf{v}^{ op} abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_ heta(\mathbf{x}) ight)^2 ight]+ ext{const}\]
  • \[\mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext { extbf{v} }}}\mathbb{E}_{p_{ ext {data }}} \left[ \mathbf{v}^T abla_{\mathbf{x}} \mathcal{F}_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}) \mathbf{v} + rac{1}{2} \left\Vert \mathbf{v}^T \mathcal{F}_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}) ight\lVert_2^2 ight]\]

Denoising score matching

The objective is:

\[E_{q_{\sigma}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}\mid\mathbf{x})} E_{\mathbf{x} \sim p(\mathbf{x})} \left[ \left\Vert s_{ heta}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}) - abla_{ ilde{\mathbf{x}}} \log q_{\sigma}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}\mid\mathbf{x}) ight\lVert_2^2 ight]\]

However, it should be noted that \(s_{ heta}(\mathbf{x}) = abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log q_{\sigma}(\mathbf{x}) \approx abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p(\mathbf{x})\) is only true when the noise is small enough to consider that \(q_{\sigma}(\mathbf{x}) \approx p(\mathbf{x})\), if we choose the noise distribution to be \(q_{\sigma}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}\mid\mathbf{x})=\mathcal{N}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}\mid\mathbf{x}, \sigma^{2}\mathbf{I})\), then we have \( abla_{ ilde{\mathbf{x}}} \log q_{\sigma}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}\mid\mathbf{x}) = rac{ ilde{\mathbf{x}} - \mathbf{x}}{\sigma^{2}}\). Therefore, the denoising score matching loss simply becomes:

\[\mathcal{l}( heta;\sigma) = E_{q_{\sigma}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}\mid\mathbf{x})} E_{\mathbf{x} \sim p(\mathbf{x})} \left[ \left\Vert \mathcal{F}_{ heta}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}) + rac{ ilde{\mathbf{x}} - \mathbf{x}}{\sigma^{2}} ight\lVert_2^2 ight].\]

Noise conditional score networks (NCSN)

We consider a positive geometric sequence of noise variances \(\{\sigma_{i}\}_{i=1}^{L}\), choosing \(\sigma_{1}\) to be large enough to mitigate manifold issue, and satisfying \( rac{\sigma_{1}}{\sigma_{2}} = \cdots = rac{\sigma_{L-1}}{\sigma_{L}} > 1\). The goal is to train a conditional network to estimate the gradients of all perturbed data distributions, ie.

\[ orall \sigma \in \{\sigma_{i}\}_{i=1}^{L}, s_{ heta}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}, \sigma) \approx abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log q_{\sigma}(\mathbf{x})\]

The objective

\[\mathcal{l}( heta;\sigma) = E_{q_{\sigma}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}\mid\mathbf{x})} E_{\mathbf{x} \sim p(\mathbf{x})} \left[ \left\Vert s_{ heta}( ilde{\mathbf{x}}, \sigma) + rac{ ilde{\mathbf{x}} - \mathbf{x}}{\sigma^{2}} ight\lVert_2^2 ight]\]

this objective can be combined to obtain a single unified objective as:

\[\mathcal{L}( heta;\{\sigma_{i}\}_{i=1}^{L}) = rac{1}{L} \sum_{i=1}^{L} \lambda(\sigma_{i})\mathcal{l}( heta;\sigma_{i})\]

where \(\lambda(\sigma_{i}) > 0\) is a coefficient function depending on \(\sigma_{i}\).

Sampling with Langevin dynamics

  • Langevin dynamics can produce samples from a probability density \(p(\mathbf{x})\)using only the score function \( abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p(\mathbf{x})\).

  • \[ ilde{\mathbf{x}}_t = ilde{\mathbf{x}}_{t-1} + rac{\epsilon}{2} abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p( ilde{\mathbf{x}}_{t-1}) + \sqrt{\epsilon} \mathbf{z}_t\]
  • a Metropolis-Hastings update is ignored
  • Inaccurate score estimation with score matching in regions of low data density
  • Annealed Langevin dynamic samples
entry.summary: Gradients can be ill-deﬁned and hard to estimate when the data resides on low-dimensional manifolds.
